title: Reality TV producer Marion Farrelly reveals the dark warning she gives future stars
text:
She's produced some of the biggest reality shows, and now Marion Farrelly has revealed just what it takes to appear on reality TV.

In an interview with The Feed for SBS VICELAND, Marion confessed it only takes her 'three seconds' to decide if someone has what it takes to appear on reality TV.

But she added she'd give them 30 seconds to convince her if she happened to be feeling 'very generous'.

Tricks of the trade: She's produced some of the biggest reality shows, and now Marion Farrelly (pictured) has revealed just what it takes to appear on reality TV in an interview with The Feed for SBS VICELAND

With shows such as The Apprentice, Farmer Wants a Wife and The X Factor under her belt, Marion claimed putting 'smart people' on reality TV is a 'dreadful mistake'.

She said intelligent people have a tendency to censor themselves, which often doesn't make for compelling viewing.

And Marion revealed she gives future reality TV stars what she's dubbed the 'Talk of Doom' before they appear.

Claims: Marion claimed putting 'smart people' on reality TV is a 'dreadful mistake'. Pictured, Martha Kalifatidis (left) and Jessika Power (right) on Married At First Sight

She confessed she's given the spiel so many times, she can still recite the damning speech from memory.

She tells them: 'You will leave here and you will be too famous to go back to your job, but not famous enough to be famous, so you probably won't work for two years.'

'If you're a guy, people will want to fight you in the pub. If you're a girl, no one will want to date you.'

Her hard truth: 'If you're a guy, people will want to fight you in the pub. If you're a girl, no one will want to date you,' she said of reality TV stars. Pictured, Matt Agnew and Abbie Chatfield on The Bachelor

'Everyone you have ever slept with will come forward and they will tell their stories to the press.'

And she said people often think they'll come off a lot more likable on TV than they actually do.

'When was the last time you were in the bar and you saw someone from TV, and you went, "Oh my God, there's that idiot from the telly!" Now, you don't think the idiot will be you, but it probably will be,' she finished.

authors: Demeter Stamell For Daily Mail Australia
